title: How to Fix the “iPhone Unavailable” Message: Explanation and Fixes

steps.title: “iPhone Unavailable” is your iPhone’s Security Lockout.
steps.content: “iPhone Unavailable” is your iPhone’s Security Lockout. If the passcode to unlock your iPhone is entered incorrectly five times, the “iPhone Unavailable” screen will appear with a message that says “try again in 1 minute.” [1] X Research source The amount of time between attempts will increase with each incorrect passcode. After 6 attempts, you'll see "iPhone Unavailable, try again in 5 minutes." After 7 attempts, you'll see "iPhone Unavailable, try again in 15 minutes." After 8 and 9 attempts, you'll see "iPhone Unavailable, try again in 60 minutes." After 10 attempts, you'll see "iPhone Unavailable," with no timer. At this point, the iPhone will need to be restored. It can no longer be unlocked. [2] X Research source If you previously selected “Erase Data” in your passcode settings, the iPhone’s data will be erased automatically.

steps.title: Enter your passcode after the timer ends.
steps.content: Enter your passcode after the timer ends. After the time specified in the “try again in [time]” message passes, you can try to enter your iPhone passcode again. If the passcode has been entered incorrectly ten times, the “iPhone Unavailable” screen will no longer show the “try again” message. Continue to the next method to reset your iPhone.

steps.title: Tap Erase iPhone.
steps.content: Tap Erase iPhone . This button will appear in the bottom-right corner of the “iPhone Unavailable” screen. [3] X Research source If this option doesn’t appear on the screen, you’ll need to reset your iPhone using iTunes with the method below. You can also potentially erase your iPhone by accessing Find My on your computer .

steps.title: Tap Erase iPhone again.
steps.content: Tap Erase iPhone again. This will confirm that you want to erase your iPhone data. You’ll be able to restore your iPhone using a backup.

steps.title: Type in your Apple ID password.
steps.content: Type in your Apple ID password. This will sign you out of Apple ID on your iPhone. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Tap Erase iPhone.
steps.content: Tap Erase iPhone . This will delete all of the settings and data on the phone. [5] X Research source

steps.title: Set up your iPhone.
steps.content: Set up your iPhone. Your iPhone will restart after erasing the data. You can restore the settings and data from a backup.

steps.title: Unplug and turn off your iPhone.
steps.content: Unplug and turn off your iPhone. Disconnect your iPhone from any cables. Completely power off your iPhone before continuing to the next step. This method will connect your iPhone to iTunes on your computer to reset the phone. [6] X Research source

steps.title: Locate the recovery mode button.
steps.content: Locate the recovery mode button. This step requires pressing and holding a specific button on your iPhone and immediately connecting it to your computer using a cable. Here are the different buttons for various iPhone models: [7] X Research source Side button (power button) - iPhone 8, iPhone 8 Plus, iPhone X and later, iPhone SE (2nd and 3rd generation) Volume down button - iPhone 7, iPhone 7 Plus Home button - iPhone SE (1st generation), iPhone 6s and earlier

steps.title: Press and hold the recover button, then connect it to your computer.
steps.content: Press and hold the recover button, then connect it to your computer. Plug in the cable to your iPhone immediately after pressing the button. [8] X Research source Continue to hold the button until the recovery mode screen appears on your phone. Then, you can let go of the button. If the passcode screen or “iPhone Unavailable” screen appears, turn off the phone and try again.

steps.title: Open iTunes on your computer.
steps.content: Open iTunes on your computer. This can be on a Windows or Mac device. iTunes may be called “Apple Music” on some Mac devices. [9] X Research source

steps.title: Click your iPhone in the sidebar.
steps.content: Click your iPhone in the sidebar. You’ll see a pop up window saying “There is a problem with the iPhone.”

steps.title: Select Restore.
steps.content: Select Restore . This will erase the iPhone’s data and restore it to factory settings. This process may take more than 15 minutes. You’ll be given the option to restore the phone’s data using a backup. [10] X Research source
